description: Key metrics of galera nodes workload and performance

panels.description:
Query response time counts (operations) are grouped into three buckets:

* 100ms - 1s

* 1s - 10s

* > 10s

links.title: More information about Query Response Time plugin in Percona Server

panels.title: Query Response Time Distribution

panels.description: The Average Query Response Time graph shows information collected using the Response Time Distribution plugin sourced from [table INFORMATION_SCHEMA. QUERY_RESPONSE_TIME](https://www.percona.com/doc/percona-server/5.7/diagnostics/response_time_distribution.html#QUERY_RESPONSE_TIME). It computes this value across all queries by taking the sum of seconds divided by the count of queries.

links.title: More information about Query Response Time plugin in Percona Server

panels.title: Average Query Response Time

panels.description:
**MySQL Questions**

The number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries used in the QPS calculation. 

This variable does not count the following commands:
* ``COM_PING``
* ``COM_STATISTICS``
* ``COM_STMT_PREPARE``
* ``COM_STMT_CLOSE``
* ``COM_STMT_RESET``
panels.title: Galera Questions

panels.description:
**MySQL Slow Queries**

Slow queries are defined as queries being slower than the long_query_time setting. For example, if you have long_query_time set to 3, all queries that take longer than 3 seconds to complete will show on this graph.
panels.title: MySQL Slow Queries

panels.description:
**InnoDB Row Operations**

This graph allows you to see which operations occur and the number of rows affected per operation. A graph like Queries Per Second will give you an idea of queries, but one query could effect millions of rows.
panels.title: InnoDB Row Read Operations

panels.description: **Query eff**
panels.title: MySQL Rows Read/Sent

panels.description:
**InnoDB Row Operations**

This graph allows you to see which operations occur and the number of rows affected per operation. A graph like Queries Per Second will give you an idea of queries, but one query could effect millions of rows.
panels.title: InnoDB Row Write (Update) Operations

panels.description:
**Query eff**
Rows sent / Rows read

targets.expr:
sum ((rate(mysql_global_status_rows_sent{}[$interval]) or irate(mysql_global_status_rows_sent{}[5m])) * on (instance) group_left mysql_galera_variables_info{wsrep_cluster_name="$cluster"}) / 
sum ((rate(mysql_global_status_rows_read{}[$interval]) or irate(mysql_global_status_rows_read{}[5m]))* on (instance) group_left mysql_galera_variables_info{wsrep_cluster_name="$cluster"})

panels.title: MySQL Query Efficiency

panels.description:
Description: Number of joins which used a full scan of the first table. 
    Select Scan is how many queries caused full table scans, in which all the data in the table had to be read and either discarded or returned.
panels.title: MySQL Select Scan

panels.description:
**InnoDB Row Operations**

This graph allows you to see which operations occur and the number of rows affected per operation. A graph like Queries Per Second will give you an idea of queries, but one query could effect millions of rows.
panels.title: InnoDB Row Write (Insert/Delete) Operations

panels.description:
Description: Number of joins which did not use an index. If not zero, you may need to check table indexes. 
    Select Full Join is the number of joins that are not joined on an index, this is usually a huge performance hit.
panels.title: MySQL Select Full Join

panels.description:
**InnoDB I/O**

_Data Writes_ - The total number of InnoDB data writes.\
_Data Reads_ - The total number of InnoDB data reads (OS file reads).\
_Log Writes_ - The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.\
_Data Fsyncs_ - The number of fsync() operations. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the `innodb_flush_method` configuration option.
panels.title: Galera InnoDB I/O - Reads

panels.description: Total time in milliseconds spent getting InnoDB row locks. / Number of times InnoDB had to wait before getting a row lock.
panels.title: InnoDB Waits

panels.description:
**InnoDB I/O**

_Data Writes_ - The total number of InnoDB data writes.\
_Data Reads_ - The total number of InnoDB data reads (OS file reads).\
_Log Writes_ - The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.\
_Data Fsyncs_ - The number of fsync() operations. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the `innodb_flush_method` configuration option.
panels.title: Galera InnoDB I/O - Writes

_Data Reads_ - The total number of InnoDB data reads (OS file reads).\
_Log Writes_ - The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.\

**InnoDB I/O**

_Data Writes_ - The total number of InnoDB data writes.\
_Data Reads_ - The total number of InnoDB data reads (OS file reads).\
_Log Writes_ - The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.\
_Data Fsyncs_ - The number of fsync() operations. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the `innodb_flush_method` configuration option.
panels.title: Galera InnoDB I/O

panels.description:
**InnoDB Checkpoint Age**

The maximum checkpoint age is determined by the total length of all transaction log files (`innodb_log_file_size`).

When the checkpoint age reaches the maximum checkpoint age, blocks are flushed syncronously. The rules of the thumb is to keep one hour of traffic in those logs and let the checkpointing perform its work as smooth as possible. If you don't do this, InnoDB will do synchronous flushing at the worst possible time, ie when you are busiest.
panels.title: InnoDB Checkpoint Age (LSN diff) (innodb metrics)

targets.legendFormat: min of nodes - Log Writen Bytes
max of nodes - Log Writen Bytes

panels.description:
**InnoDB I/O**

_Data Writes_ - The total number of InnoDB data writes.\
_Data Reads_ - The total number of InnoDB data reads (OS file reads).\
_Log Writes_ - The number of physical writes to the InnoDB redo log file.\
_Data Fsyncs_ - The number of fsync() operations. The frequency of fsync() calls is influenced by the setting of the `innodb_flush_method` configuration option.
panels.title: Galera InnoDB Fsyncs Data/Log (+/-)

panels.description:
**Top Command Counters**

The Com_{{xxx}} statement counter variables indicate the number of times each xxx statement has been executed. There is one status variable for each type of statement. For example, Com_delete and Com_update count [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements, respectively. Com_delete_multi and Com_update_multi are similar but apply to [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements that use multiple-table syntax.
panels.title: Top Command Counters

panels.description:
**Top Command Counters Hourly**

The Com_{{xxx}} statement counter variables indicate the number of times each xxx statement has been executed. There is one status variable for each type of statement. For example, Com_delete and Com_update count [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements, respectively. Com_delete_multi and Com_update_multi are similar but apply to [``DELETE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/delete.html) and [``UPDATE``](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/update.html) statements that use multiple-table syntax.
panels.title: Top Command Counters (increase per $incr_interval)

panels.description:
**MySQL Network Traffic**

Here we can see how much network traffic is generated by MySQL. Outbound is network traffic sent from MySQL and Inbound is network traffic MySQL has received.
panels.title: Galera Sql Network Traffic

title: Galera WorkLoad Overview
